>
> I'm evolving an extens=
ion of Stanley & Miikulainen's robot duel domain
> in ANJI 2.01, but I'm ha=
ving trouble setting the speciation threshold.
> If I set it too high, all =
of my 100 chromosomes will (of course) stay
> in one specie. But when I set=
 it a bit lower, I end up with 100
> species of 1 chromosome after some 100=
 generations. I can't seem to
> find the golden middle. On his FAQ
> (http:=
//www.cs.utexas.edu/users/kstanley/neat.html), Kenneth Stanley
> himself pr=
esents a method to automatically set the speciation
> threshold by descreas=
ing or increasing it with, say, 0.3, whenever the
> number of species becom=
es more or less than a preset target amount of,
> say, 10.
>
> However, whe=
n I apply this method (with population size 100 and target
> species count =
10), then after some 100 generations I end up with 20 to
> 25 species and a=
 speciation threshold of 40 and rising. Of the
> resulting species, one spe=
cie contains 50 chromosomes, 10 species
> contain 5 chromosomes or less and=
 10 species contain just one chromosome.
>
> Has anyone else encountered su=
ch problems before, or have some idea to
> what might be causing this? How =
do you keep a 'normal' amount of more
> or less equally sized species?

Hi =
Bas,

I thought I'd chime in and back the conversation up a little from
imp=
lementation to theory.

Why are we using speciation (and along with it expl=
icit fitness
sharing) to begin with?  I thought the idea was that new speci=
es
represented forays into new areas of the search space, and that
explicit=
 fitness sharing was a way to initially protect these
exploratory jumps.

O=
bviously you don't want just 1 species in your population, or the
other ext=
reme, where every individual is in its own species.  But the
description ab=
ove "one specie contains 50 chromosomes, 10 species
contain 5 chromosomes o=
r less and 10 species contain just one
chromosome" actually sounds just fin=
e to me...not a "problem" at all. 
Seems to me that if you restrict the num=
ber of species to something
like 7 species, then if you have a significantl=
y different
architecture arise, it's going to just get lumped in with an ex=
isting
species, and this new "experimental" topology may be watered down by=

crossover.

I can understand the rationale for restricting the number of s=
pecies,
but it also seems more organic to let the number of species fluctua=
te
as long as you don't end up with either extreme.  And above all, how
is =
the fitness improving?  Ken did ablation tests with and without
speciation,=
 but it might be worthwhile to look at differences between
fixed and fluid =
speciation (though I would suspect that there wouldn't
be a substantial dif=
ference in performance).

Derek
